The Obelisk Gate Written by N. K. Jemisin

The second book in the Broken Earth trilogy picks up where the first left off. The planet has been torn open by Alabster and Essun is looking for her missing daughter.

Contains spoilers

üìï What It's About

In the previous book, Alabaster tapped into the power of the obelisks and tore a giant rift in the continent, exposing a drastic amount of geological stuff and triggering the current ‚ÄòFifth Season‚Äô.

Elsewhere, we learn that Essun‚Äôs husband Jija, beat their son Uche to death after learning that he was an orogene. Jija then takes their daughter Nassun and leaves town. The Obelisk Gate begins with Jija and Nassun going north to a town that her father believes has the ‚Äòcure‚Äô for orogeny.

Essun is trying to find her daughter while also trying to understand more about the obelisks, and Alabaster is dying.

üîç How I Discovered It

Immediately after finishing The Fifth Season, I purchased The Obelisk Gate and the last book of the trilogy, The Stone Sky. The first book was so damned good, finishing the trilogy was automatic for me.

üß† Thoughts

The Obelisk Gate was a bit boring when compared to The Fifth Season. The reason is that I feel like not much happened. It‚Äôs a very slow book compared to the first in the series. Also, there was a lot of information thrown at you in this book.

All of that to say, I still enjoyed it, I absolutely love the characters and their development, and I‚Äôm very much looking forward to the next book in the trilogy.

What I Liked About It

I loved how we finally get to learn more about Essun‚Äôs daughter, Nassun. She didn‚Äôt get very much page-time in the first book but she‚Äôs basically featured in half of The Obelisk Gate. Her orogeny powers are rapidly growing and I suspect there‚Äôs going to be a showdown between her and her mother.

Another thing I liked about The Obelisk Gate is that we‚Äôre finally learning more about these mysterious ‚Äòthings‚Äô called the stone-eaters. They were still surrounded by a mist of wonder after the first book and now the reading is beginning to get an understanding of their purpose and motives. Although they differ from stone-eater to stone-eater it seems.

Also, I love Alabaster and Schaffa. I think they‚Äôre great characters. These two have been the highlight of the series for me so far.

What I Didn't Like About It

As I eluded to earlier, The Obelisk Gate is boring at times. There were times where I‚Äôd read a large paragraph and thought to myself, ‚ÄúI could have just skipped that.‚Äù That‚Äôs really the only complaint I have.

ü¶âWho Would Like It?

If you loved the first book, you have to read this one as well.
